subject: PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIA STOCK NEWS: WTI rose above USD 71.00/bbl; Japan and South Korea are shut for holiday
content:
AUSTRALIA

South32 (S32 AT) – Co. provides update on Cerro Matosis litigation in which it will have to pay damages to the community, but states production is unaffected by the ruling. (Newswires)

Lynas (LYC AT) - Media speculates that Malaysia may conduct a review on Co. operations in the country. (Newswires)

Immutep (IMM AT) – Co. announces a trial collaboration and supply agreement with Pfizer (PFE) and Merck (MRK GY). (Newswires)

Sims Metal Management (SGM AU) – Guides Q1 underlying EBIT AUD 58-63mln vs. Prev. AUD 45mln. (Newswires)

Scottish Pacific (SCO AT) – Co. has endorsed a USD 600mln-plus takeover offer from private equity firm Affinity Equity Partners. (AFR)

Regis Resources (RRL AT) – Co. confirms it proposed to purchase Capricorn Metals (CMM AT) at AUD 0.144/shr vs. last close AUD 0.059. (Newswires)

ENERGY

Oil prices rose to break above USD 71.00/bbl. (Newswires)

OTHER NEWS

Polls suggested Australian PM Morrison increased lead against opposition head Shorten to 45% vs. 32% (Prev. 42% vs. 36%). (Newswires)

JAPAN

ORIX (8591 JT) – Co. is interested in taking a majority stake in IL&FS (ILFS IS). (Newswires)

Renesas Electronics (6723 JT) – Co. seeks to increase revenues by selling proprietary semiconductor designs. Co. will start licensing 40 chip designs, including processors and memory chips. (Nikkei)

Kyowa Hakko Kirin (4151 JT) – Co. announces positive CHMP opinions for Mogamulizumab for the treatment of Mycosis Fungoides and Sezary Syndrome. (Newswires)

Oracle (4716 JT) – Report Q1 net JPY 9.4bln vs. Prev. JPY 8.5bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Mazda (7261 JT) – Co. warns of a USD 248mln hit to operating profits due to output reduction from Japanese floods. (Nikkei)

Mitsui (8031 JT) – Co. are to partner with Mitsui Sugar to acquire Singapore firm SIS with terms undisclosed. (Newswires)

Suntory (2587 JT) – Co. is seeking to increase prices for shipments of Bourbon to EU. (Nikkei)

Tosoh (4042 JT) – Co.’s Vinyl unit are to end output at their Osaka plant in FY 2020. (Newswires)

SOUTH KOREA

Hanwha (000880 KS) – Co. and Korean Midland Power are to build a solar power plant in the US by 2020. (Newswires)

Samsung Electronics (005930 KS) – Co.’s cooktops receive the highest scores from the US Consumer Report; according to an industry source. (Yonhap)

POSCO (005490 KS) – Co. CEO says inter-Korean summit to create new opportunities for the steel industry. (Newswires)

Insurance names – South Korea’s financial regulator said that limits will be placed on hiking premiums of indemnity insurance in 2019. (Yonhap)

OTHER NEWS

- OECD reduces South Korea 2018 forecast to 2.7% (Prev. 3.0%); 2019 forecast 2.8% (Prev. 3.0%). (Newswires)

- South Korea job seekers who have “given up” on looking for work rose by 5.4% Y/Y to a record 510K in August. (Newswires)

- Companies in Korea, Taiwan and Japan have begun shifting output from China amid US tariffs. (Newswires)

- US Secretary of State Pompeo said the US is working on a second Trump-Kim meeting, but work still needs to be done to get the right conditions. (Newswires)

subject: Iran revolutionary guards threatened retaliation for the attack on the Iranian military parade; although it is not clear who they will retaliate against
analysis_details: • As a reminder, there was a shooting at a military parade in Iran that was claimed by anti-government group as well IS militants, while Iranian President Rouhani criticised the US and Gulf states as having enabled the attack.

subject: UK's Labour Party are to vote on a motion this week to keep all options on the table, including a second Brexit referendum if the party cannot get a national election
OECD reduces South Korea 2018 forecast to 2.7% (Prev. 3.0%); 2019 forecast 2.8% (Prev. 3.0%)
ASIAN DAILY ECONOMIC RELEASES CALENDAR NOW AVAILABLE IN THE RESEARCH SECTION: Light calendar with several closures in the region

Oil prices edge higher in early trade after weekend reports that OPEC sees large growth in supply and demand over the next 5 years, while Saudi said it is highly unlikely output will be raised next year
US equities are lower amid a risk averse tone after China cancelled trade talks with the US and US tariffs on USD 200bln worth of Chinese goods set to come into effect today
US government has delayed imposing sanction on Rusal (486 HK)
Singapore is expected to upgrade its free trade agreement with China
Companies in Korea, Taiwan and Japan have begun shifting output from China amid US tariffs
DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

China has cancelled upcoming trade talks with the US. (WSJ) In related news, there were comments from US President Trump stating the US have a lot more tariffs if China retaliates. (Newswires)
Note: US tariffs on USD 200bln are set to come into effect today.

White House Official said on Friday US goal is not to divorce US and Chinese economies, while the official added it would not be good for long term growth, and if China continues on its path, there is a risk that companies may move their supply chains. (Newswires)

UK

UK PM May said she will set out an alternative proposal. and that neither side should demand the unacceptable of the other, while May added the UK cannot accept anything that does not respect referendum result. (Newswires)

UK PM May said both the EU and UK want a deal but dismissed the EU's two offered options saying they are not appropriate for the UK. May once again reiterated UK will not accept an internal border and said anything that fails to respect the referendum would be a bad deal. Furthermore, she added EU's Tusk said Chequers would undermine the single market but did not explain how. (Newswires)

UK PM May’s aides have reportedly begun contingency planning for a snap election in November to save the Brexit talks and her job after EU leaders rebuffed the PM’s Chequers plan. Strategists have begun “war-gaming” an autumn vote to win public backing for a new plan. (Times) However, there were also reports UK Brexit Secretary Raab dismissed claims of a snap general election in Autumn, while playing down the chances of the government pivoting towards a Canada-style deal and EU officials are also thought to be working on a counter-proposal to Chequers, which is likely to appear in early October. (Guardian)

Labour leader, Jeremy Corbyn plans to use Conservative Brexit rebels to force PM May into a General Election as early as November. Furthermore, the Labour leader will reluctantly back a second EU referendum if his party conference calls for it. (Daily Mirror)

Jeremy Hosking, a City financier who donated GBP 1.5mln to the Leave campaign and has given GBP 375k to the Conservatives since 2015, is threatening to fund a new pro-Brexit party if PM May fails to deliver on the EU referendum. (Telegraph)

EU's Tusk said the UK knew EU's position on Chequers for weeks and that EU fully respects UK's Brexit decision, while he added a compromise is still possible and he is focused on getting a deal that would minimise damage resulting from Brexit. Furthermore, Tusk said EU will treat Chequers plan as a step in the right direction. (Newswires)

DUP Leader Foster said the DUP would veto any new barrier between UK and Northern Ireland. (Newswires)

Dutch PM Rutte said the EU would still like to make a Brexit deal, but the UK must take steps. (Newswires)


EU

Italy's League said Economy Minister Tria acknowledged the political will of League and 5-Star, adding steps for are to be adopted for change. He added he would look for budget solutions to perfect both League and 5-Star proposals. (Newswires)

Italy’s League leader Salvini say the meeting on budget was very positive. (Newswires)

Fitch affirmed Switzerland at 'AAA'; Outlook Stable and affirmed Norway at 'AAA'; Outlook Stable. S&P raised Latvia’s rating one notch to A from A-; outlook revised to stable from positive. (Newswires)

FX

Canadian Retail Sales MM Jul 0.3% vs. Exp. 0.4% (Prev. -0.2%, Rev. -0.1%)

Canadian CPI Inflation MM Aug -0.1% vs. Exp. -0.1% (Prev. 0.5%)

Canadian CPI Inflation YY Aug 2.8% vs. Exp. 2.8% (Prev. 3.0%)

COMMODITIES

OPEC+ affirmed plans to gradually continue increasing crude output in-line with the summer decision. Saudi’s Energy Minster al-Falih said the country’s output will largely depend on demand which he thinks will be higher in October, while he added producers have enough capacity to meet unexpected market situations. Furthermore, he stated 100% compliance is not a fixed production target and countries in the past 3 months have opened taps to compensate for Iran. (Newswires)

OPEC+ monitoring compliance rose to 129% in August from 109% in July, while there were separate source reports on Friday OPEC and Non-OPEC countries discussed a 0.5mln BPD increase. (Newswires)

Saudi Arabia was said to be concerned about oil prices being above USD 80, according to sources that added Saudis are running low of Arab Light for October allocations. (WSJ)

Baker Hughes Rig Count (21 Sep): Oil rigs -1 at 866, gas rigs unchanged at 186, total rigs -2 at 1053. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

US Secretary of State Pompeo said the US is working on a second Trump-Kim meeting, but work still needs to be done to get the right conditions. (Newswires)

There was a shooting at a military parade in Iran that was claimed by anti-government group as well IS militants, while Iranian President Rouhani criticized the US and Gulf states as having enabled the attack. (BBC)

US

Canadian PM Trudeau said it is very likely that US and Canada may hold informal NAFTA talks on the sidelines of this week’s UN meeting, but no decisions have been made yet on the informal talks. (Newswires)

US is sticking to its guns on dairy in NAFTA, while the US willing to advance only with Mexico but it is up to Canada. (Newswires)

White House Advisor Hassett said they are getting 'very, very close' to having to move forward on a trade deal with Mexico and not Canada; according to a Fox News interview. (Newswires)

US House set to consider a tax 2.0 package this week. (Newswires)

MARKET RECAP

American Airlines (AAL) hiked fees for luggage handling, sending it to the top performers list; Delta Airlines (DAL) rose in sympathy. JPMorgan (JPM) raised its price target for Under Armour (UA, UAA) helping it to make the top performers list again on Friday. McDonald's (MCD) hiked its dividend, buoying consumer discretionary shares. Micron (MU) was lower, weighing on other chipmakers, after it said tariffs would weigh on its results for three/four quarters ahead. Quad witching and sector rebalancing were said to be impacting the tech sector, though Apple (AAPL) will remain in the tech sector and Amazon (AMZN) will remain in the consumer discretionary sector. Facebook (FB), Alphabet (GOOG, GOOGL) and Twitter (TWTR) will be reclassified as communication companies rather than tech stocks. Copart (CPRT) was downgraded at JPMorgan. General Motors (GM) was lower on reported option activity. Darden (DRI) saw profit-taking after hitting record highs on Thursday, and after a number of broker PT hikes. SPX -0.06% at 2929, NDX -0.5% at 7531, DJI +0.29% at 26731.

News flow generally had little impact on the complex; volumes and ranges were thinner ahead of next week’s FOMC meeting, leaving the bias for yields to dip slightly, though not more than 1bps across the curve. There is USD 233bln on the supply slate for next week, including 2s, 5s, and 7s. US T-note futures (Z8) settled 2+ ticks higher at 118-21.

subject: ASIA-PAC SERVICE IS NOW LIVE FOR TODAY'S SESSION
